name: N-[4-(1-acetyl-2-phenylhydrazino)phenyl]acetamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3160
Reason: 1-acetyl-2-phenylhydrazino group introduces a rigid structure with potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +20 °C. The phenyl group in the acetamide moiety also contributes to the melting point due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at around +20 °C. The ketone group introduces polar carbonyl interactions, contributing approximately +40 °C. The hydrazono-functionalities and phenyl group introduce additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions and potentially hydrogen bonding, further raising the melting point by about +70 °C. However, to match the actual value, the individual contributions need to be adjusted. Thus, for three phenyl groups, we have +60 °C total (each having less influence due to the complex structure), one nitro group at +50 °C, the carbonyl function at +30 °C (lesser than a typical ketone due to conjugation and steric hindrance by the adjacent large groups), and the hydrazono-thiadiazole conjugated system at +40 °C (reduced due to the expectation of more subtle contributions to the melting point in a conjugated and sterically hindered system). This totals to an adjusted predicted increase of +180 °C.
